												The Hat Man: Shadow Ward is a indie horror game.Your daughter is assigned to an asylum because of attempting suicide. Somehow she has gone missing and it is up to you to find her.At the beginning you can choose if you play as the father or the mother (no difference to game, just difference voices).Soon after the start you will realize that The Hat Man is nothing more as another Slender clone. You move through the rooms and try to find all pages (notes from your daughter) while the Hat Man is trying to chase you.The Hat Man is fairly slow and not a real danger at all. You can easily walk through the rooms and collect the pages. To finish the game it takes something around 30 minutes.The graphics are not great at all. The whole game is very repetitive, all rooms look the same.The sound is okay but the voice acting is really awful.The Hat Man: Shadow Ward is not scary at all and especially not worth 4,99€ (former price was 14,99€).Sounds 3/10Graphics 3/10Gameplay 2/10Atmosphere 2/10If you liked my review, please feel free to follow me and/or my curator group:http://steamcommunity.com/id/Ov3RT4K3R/myworkshopfiles/?section=guideshttp://steamcommunity.com/groups/orcollective#curationAlso feel free to check out my YouTube Channel: https://www.youtube.com/channel/UC83DYCmrWfl9ttrhX54jmWA

YouTube™ Video: The Hat Man: Shadow Ward [Game Review] 

			Views: 1,565		

			My review of "The Hat Man: Shadow Ward", a first-person survival horror game set in an asylum developed and published by Game Mechanics.		

Game: The Hat Man: Shadow WardGenre: Survival horrorDeveloper: Game MechanicsPublisher: Game MechanicsCopy supplied by developerThe Hat Man: Shadow Ward is a first-person survival horror game set in an asylum developed and published by Game Mechanics.STORYYou play as either the father or mother of Virginia Berry, who disappeared from the asylum where she was being treated for attempting suicide. As you go and investigate her disappearance, you find no one in the asylum and you start looking for pages from your daughter's journal while being chased by a shadowy figure.Unlike most horror games of this nature, reading the notes and discovering what your daughter was living through is more interesting than simply looking at doodles and drawings of the monster. Unfortunately, the plot really goes nowhere and is disposable at best for the game.GRAPHICSAs far as Unity games go, this doesn't stand out from the crowd. The environments are polished and I didn't encounter a single bug, but the rooms all look the same and it becomes really hard to navigate the environment. The design of the titular villain and the shadow people isn't really scary, and once you see them the built-up scariness disappears.GAMEPLAYSimilarly to Slenderman: The Eight Pages, you must move through the environment looking for pages while avoiding being caught by the Hat Man. You will also need to find some objects to open new areas and further explore the asylum. The pages are really easy to find since they make a noise when you are near them, and the shadow people can be "defeated" by hitting'em with your flashlight "Alan Wake style".CHALLENGEThe game is really easy to beat, and the antagonist showed up rarely and was really slow and easy to avoid.SOUNDThe voice acting for both the father and mother is hilariously bad, and that alone is worth playing the game. There is only one piece of music, and is the relaxing one that plays at the radio. There are also some ambient noises, and luckily no screamers or loud jumpscares.REPLAYABILITYAfter having beaten the game, you can replay it to unlock the 11 achievements that require you to beat the game as fast as possible and find and listen to all the diary pages.The game is creepy most of the times, but the boring level design, poorly developed ghosts and short length make the game feel more boring than it needed to be. However, I recommend this game for the voice acting and really cheap price to support the developers to create a better product.Story: 6
Graphics: 7

Sound: 5
Replayability: 4

ry 18, 2015
												Prepare to die screaming…or more likely laughing at the horrendously bad voice acting of ‘The Hat Man: The 20+ Pages’……wait….wrong game (and more on the voice acting later).  Alas, just as has happened with so many other indie horror games in recent years and with the advent of the Slender series, ‘The Hat Man:  Shadow Ward’ (the ‘for real’ name) falls victim to the same ‘collect quest’ gameplay  mechanic.  This means that you need to find a set number of pages from your daughter’s diary to complete the game.  Ultimately, that’s the basis of the game:  you either play as the father or mother in search of said daughter, who has gone missing from the seemingly empty asylum she was committed to which is now populated by shadow people/The Hat Man (BTW – the idea of shadow peeps is based loosely on fact and there are many documented cases, and even some decent movies, about people that have seen or had encounters with these so-called ‘Shadow People’).  Thankfully, you don’t just search for pages as you also need to find some other items to progress deeper into the asylum and defeat The Hat Man (who I guess is like the pimp of the shadow peeps) to get your daughter back.One of the more unique attributes of this game (though it’s been done before) is that sound is utilized to pinpoint the location of pages/other items you need by means of whispery voices.  Also, the sound design of this game isn’t half bad for being a budget title, with some of the sound effects/ambient music being pretty creepy in my opinion. Now as promised, I must go back to my earlier comment about the voice acting.  Granted, this game is super short and can be beat in less than half an hour, so you may think that voice acting wouldn’t be too important in such a game…..but it kinda, sorta totally is.  Essentially, it’s hilarious.  No, seriously, I’m not joking.  I mean, it’s so stupendously bad that it’s good (I don’t know how that works; it defies the human intellect to comprehend how that can be) but it’s true.  I figure most people will laugh at it, though some may actually want to cry at how bad it is.  And for all those 100% achievement unlock Steamers out there – prepare thine selves!!  There is actually an achievement for listening to your daughter reading the pages of her diary as you collect them.  Sure, this game can fairly easily be ‘100%’d’ and the aforementioned achievement is easy enough to unlock, but don’t go joy-puking your faces off just yet as I seriously believe that listening to all of the pages may very well land you in an asylum. I personally just barely managed to keep my sanity intact while unlocking this achievement, so don’t say I didn’t warn you.This game can be fun for like 2 hrs tops, but I wouldn’t recommend it at full price, even if it is a budget title. With decent voice acting, who knows, perhaps this game could have been terrifying.  As it is, it will likely be overlooked by most gamers, but it is somewhat interesting and good for a laugh….or cry, so give it a shot.

												“The Scariest Game of 2014”?I know these marketing techniques and they usually don't influence me, but I still went ahead and bought this game for like 25 cents because, why not? One can argue that for the price any game is worth it, except The Slaughtering Grounds, but actually there's games that are pretty much similar or even better and they don't ask for a penny. With all due respect to the developers, this game is an attempt at being something and I can see it, but fails due to the large amount of bugs and many other problems. I'm really nit-picky so I will address a lot of things in this review that most people maybe don't have a problem with.When booting the game, I recognize the Unity launcher right away. Me and Unity games usually don't go well, but I can't judge a game by it's launcher obviously... Then the game boots up and a crazy amount of FPS makes me almost certain I'm going to have tearing issues, so I check Settings, only to find out that there's no option for VSync. I thought this was a standard in game options by now! Key bindings are pretty simple and I did try to change the inventory up and down bindings to my mouse wheel and it doesn't work so I'll just stick to the T and G keys, I had never done that, and it's terrible.Finally I choose Play, and I pick to play as the Father. Upon the first second of the game... there it is, the damn screen tearing all over the place. Quite hard to ignore but since most of the game is dark as hell, I give it a pass. So, I go upstairs, touch a book and the game has officially started. So the first complaint is, although I know a lot of people just skip it nowadays but, tutorials please. I had no idea what I should be doing and how should I progress, you can't expect me to rely on the internet to find out how to escape or kill a damn ghost that just clips through the wall and grabs you in the first SECONDS. Turns out I just needed to Zoom my lantern in her face and she dies. Then it seems I have to pickup... pages? Wait isn't this like that game where you're in the woods and... yes it is. You're pretty much lying if you say this game isn't a copy of Slender: The Eight Pages inside 4 walls because it clearly is. What it does differently is the fact that this is randomly generated, and it works well for the most part. You go right pass 3 rooms, and if you go back the map has changed. This is actually very interesting and an idea that I found to be wasted on a game like this.So you do get the book and those pages, and finally enter this sort of asylum, this is where you seek the pages that your daughter wrote, as this is some sort of dream that you got to save her from. Upon collecting the fifth page, when the little 5 green balls are lit now on my HUD (which I had no idea what they were for like 2 hours), the almighty, spooky and fearsome enemy spawns. One of the main flaws in this game is the so called "Hat man", because he's just laughable, he just floats and follows you trying to catch you. Which he will never do since you can outrun him easily. Then he despawns somehow. This is the whole game, or pretty much all of it. Then again I do say, the lack of tutorials make this game so much harder than it is, no one actually gives you any tips on how to evade the Hatman or even progress in the game. The journal pages do give you tips but I don't feel it's enough for the player to actually understand what he has to do. Just to clarify, the little orbs in the HUD indicate that a new item to progress in the game has spawned and is now placed in the random rooms, so you need to find 5 pages for each new item to progress in the game.Another complaint I have is, sound effects. You might ask, what sound effects? Exactly, there's barely any. When I die, playing as the father by the way, the sound of me getting caught is of a woman, what the hell. Also, the Hatman himself hardly makes any kind of noise, he doesn't even make a sound when he catches you...The Hatman spawns are literally the only thing in this game that makes it hard and infuriating to say the least. And when you get cornered there's no way to go, making it such a cheap way to make you lose. Since there's a lack of manual saving, you're only allowed to save if you find certain save points, but these are hard to come by and you will lose a lot of progress. Also, the worst thing is when you've made good progress and the Hatman literally just clips through the damn floor and kills you. That made me rage-quit this game so badly I actually was about to give up on this, but I still got to the ending because I like self-torture, and achievements.The atmosphere is... good! Despite the game being flawed to hell, having a not-creepy-at-all enemy that's just annoying and the lack of sound effects, the atmosphere does feel tense, and the feeling of not knowing where you should go because the game is randomly generated does give it a feeling of anxiety, since you never know what's on the next room, it could be the spooky scarecrow or the next exit. But please take note, a scary game doesn't need to have the brightness of the ocean depths. Don't rely so much in darkness to make your game scary. I hate games that are way too dark. I know horror has to be dark, but I like playing a game, not just hearing it.As for my final thoughts... The Hat Man: Shadow Ward, is it worth your time? Sorry, it isn't. With this formula there's so many more like this, and they're probably better executed, probably free too. I always wonder if developers read these reviews and reading what I just wrote would leave me heartbroken, but I have to be honest, Hat man is a poor game and I cannot recommend it. 2/10

												I’ll admit I maybe spent longer studying The Hat Man: Shadow Ward’s death screen than it deserved. But it so nicely summed up the game for me that I couldn’t help but appreciate that I was being handed a focus point for my review without even having to look for it.But let’s step back for a moment because it’s not just the death screen important here, but how you arrive at it. After scurrying through a twisting, self replicating maze of stock textures and out of place items, you’re inevitably caught the titular Hat Man in all his floating jack-o-lantern glory. And what’s this? He’s opening his mouth and- oh, I guess that wasn’t supposed to happen.And just like that we’re transported to a perfectly flat, perfectly bland death screen featuring three buttons, each drawn with the same ugly font and taking up almost the entire screen. I realize it’s a screen that didn’t need to have much detail, but what’s here is such a pitiful excuse for a menu I couldn’t help but laugh at it.I suppose I can give The Hat Man that much anyway; it made me laugh. First at the ridiculous voice acting that I want so much to believe was intentional. Then when turning around and laying eyes on what I think was supposed to be a terrifying demon but looked more like a blazing smile.And finally at the death screen, which I saw many times and eventually decided was a good enough place to give this game a rest. After all The Hat Man is just doing his job haunting this asylum, and doing it damn well at that, so I’ll just leave him be and go do literally anything else to try to forget this ever happened.You can read more of my writing on Kritiqal[kritiqal.com].

												Here are my main gripes:Has potential, but I feel like I was ripped off when I paid 14.99 for a 250mb game. I feel like a 4.99 price tag would be more appropriate. The voice acting is painful. I'm pretty forgiving of things like this, but wow. It actually made the game less scary because some of the comments were very out of place and sarcastic. When you're doing a horror game, the feeling needs to be raw with genuine fear. How are we supposed to be afraid if you aren't? I don't feel like I have enough time to sit and listen to the journal entries. Whenever I try to listen to or read one so I can learn about the story, hatman comes and kills me. I don't know if this is a glitch or normal, but I can't learn about the story if I get killed every time I'm reading the journal. I really wanna know what's going on with the lady's daughter but I still haven't much of a clue as to what's going on in the asylum.Here is what I liked:Running around collecting pages/piecing together a story. Some folks feel like it's too bright, but I disagree. You can't have shadows without light. When the bad voice acting wasn't ruining my immersion, I was actually scared of the hatman and rushing through the asylum trying to find everything without dying. Though I wish he was a little less agressive so that I could have more time to explore and see the rooms/read journals. So with all of this being said, I'm still trying to complete the game. These are just my opinions for right now and may likely change.

 "Hope is tomorrow's veneer over today's disappointment." The Hat Man: Shadow Ward is a first-person game developed by the company Game Mechanics with emphasis on survival. Atmosphere & presentation: + Occasionally the game succeeds to scare the player. o The randomly created corridors, rooms and items offer a certain replayability, but the multitude of negative points in the general presentation of the game decreases the motivation to play it again.o Solid sound effects create a partially threatening environment.- The player has to face only one threat in form of the Hat Man, which results in a rather low level of difficulty.- The A.I. and general collision system of the antagonist is poorly implemented, e.g. it tends to get stuck in the wall. - At the beginning the player leaves an axe behind, which negatively impacts the credibility of this ‘survival’ game. Characters & story: - Sloppy story telling. - No characterization of the protagonist.- No voice acting during the entire game.- Very short game that can be finished in less than 30 minutes. Summary: Hat Man does not work out as intended, because it has been released in an unfinished state. After 30 minutes, which it takes to finish the game, you will only remember the weak A.I., repetitive level design and sloppy story telling. Therefore, the advertising slogan 'the scariest game of 2014' can be considered a blatant lie. Achievements: Estimated time for 100 % completion: +3 hoursSingleplayer achievements: 11Multiplayer achievements: none

												So, I have to preface this game by pointing out that I was given this game for free by one of the only marketers that isn't an idiot in the industry, who handed keys for the game out free of charge to drum up press for the price drop and the free update.Ignoring that, the game isn't actually bad, but it IS something you've probably played before; this game is a slightly more involved version of Slender.If you weren't scared by Slender, or games like Slender, you won't be scared by this.This is half of why my review may or may not be something you should listen to, because quite frankly this sort of thing is fairly distant from what I consider my affair.You're chased by numerous ghosts and the HatMan, all of whom look like the bad guy from Ferngully. Also, you can find the credits to the game in a room, killing most of the atmosphere that's set by the idea that the game is based on a true story.Aside from that, the environments are very enclosed, dark asylum settings, so it raises the question of whether you'd get this for cheap, Slender for cheaper, or Amnesia/Outlast for a bit more than this.I do have to say if nothing else the game is actually reasonably priced when it's on sale for 20 cents, although five bucks may be a bit much.I'm actually a bit torn, because I don't actually see this doing too well outside of 20 cents to a buck territory, because the entire presentation is fairly amateur and ends up being something I'd compare to free unity games, but damn that marketer was nice.Can't say I can recommend this past a sale, because the actual content just isn't the sort of thing you'd usually see charged for.Also, for the half a person that cares, I think I bugged achievements so... There's that?

												A solid, low-budget first-person survival horror closely linked to  Slenderman: The Eight Pages , housing a fair amount of haunting images and thick atmosphere, evoking a handful of steady cold shivers and durable tension within its short run, mostly due to the eerie and restrained sound design.Your daughter has gone missing from the asylum where she was being treated for attempting suicide. Once you enter the vacant facility, investigating her whereabouts, you begin looking for pages from your daughter's journal while being hunted by a dark presence wearing a hat.The basic gameplay of finding a bunch of objects to unlock new areas for further exploration is quite easily comprehensible, yet it may be a fair disorienting challenge to obtain all 20+ pages since the randomly altering level design relocate the pages on each playthrough; though once you pinpoint the location of a page, whispery voices are in effect and narrowing it down become child's play.The stiff level design is utterly mediocre at best and visually it is quite dull, but the ridiculously awkward voice-over is the shattering winner to listen to and hence should have been left out. Also, the poorly written dialogue comes out far more silly rather than intriguing, and finally - considering the source material that is based on real events - the outcome turns out quite immaterial.At a discount however, coupled with appreciating solid scares, Game Mechanics' short piece of indie horror, regardless of being a Slender copy, earns a night's attention. 5,5 / 10

												This game starts with a somewhat interesting concept. You can choose between a mother and a father, which so far, the only difference that it makes is that your death scream is different. You're trapped in some kind of demonic ward, or should I say, a shadow ward? This ward is always changing, so you have to keep moving forwards all the time. You gotta collect pages, too, like in Slenderman games, but way more, and a few other items along the way like matches and levers. You pretty much run between corridors, and now and then, you'll hear some kind of whispering, telling you that there is an item in a side room. If you miss an item and leave the room, just keep running, there is no point in going back, it probably changed already.The main enemy of this game, is the Hat Man, a being that from a distance kinda looks like a trenchcoat wearing guy with a hat, surrounded in a cloud of blackness and with a purple aura. Later on, he changes to something different, that's way faster and more persistent, adding a bit of fear to the mix. That being said, the problem with these procedually generated games is that, sometimes, it's way too random. And in this game's case, sometimes you're going to be able to finish the game in less than 30 minutes, sometimes it's going to take way longer than that. It took me around 30 minutes for a room I needed to spawn. I even believed my game was bugged. The game's atmosphere is kinda creepy at first, being chased by this creature that never stops. (Actually, he does, when you enter a certain kind of room, like stairs or the room with the pit)It's got some weak jumpscares, too, like a ceiling light falling, or a wheelchair moving. The problem is, after running from the Hat Man for a while, and after seeing the same rooms and the same jumpscares over and over again over the period of....dozens of minutes....It kinda starts to get old rather fast. er 18, 2016
												If you were looking for a good horror game, don't even consider this game. Not only are the graphics absolute trash, but the whole game seems to revolve around collecting the remaining two pages in the rooms and finding items. Finding the items is an absolute nightmare and I only managed to find the crowbar, matches and a spike pit featured in the trailer video, all in one hour. That is literally how long it takes sometimes due to poor game design and repetitive room layouts. The room layout is so repetitive you easily lose your way and have difficulty even telling where you are, it's essentially a walking, searching and escaping simulator all mashed up into one. Not to mention the AI for the Hat Man is atrocious, since all it does is "teleport" to a location directly in your field of view, namely in front of you. He goes through walls and can't be shaken off, as he'll just "teleport" directly in front of you again when you have all five pages of the journal. He looks like some image taken from google and plastered onto a model and called the oh-so-scary Hat Man. As for the Shadow people, I never even encountered any of them. The only thing I'd seen that would even possibly be close to that was at the beginning when you click on the journal and a creature shows up to steal your soul, but I think even then that's just the Hat Man. It's a bit like Dead by Daylight, Slender: The Eight Pages and Vanish all combined to make this pathetic excuse for a game. You walk away and instantly the rooms have changed, making it impossible to find your way back. Some hints or even an explanation of what to do would be nice so I'm not aimlessly wandering around halls, running from the dreaded Hat Man, who's kill animation makes me want to throw up. Shockingly enough, the audio and atmosphere in the game was tolerable. Audio would get extremely repetitive, but the occasional radio playing badly done music was fairly creepy. Also a falling tile or light, whatever it was, was a good trick, but the novelty wears off really quick and you grow to expect it. Same for the mysteriously moving wheelchairs, although those can get you caught if you're unlucky (Or daft).So overall, this game isn't really something you should buy, especially at full price. If you're really that desperate to try it, wait until it goes on sale, that way you won't be as disapointed. I'm disgusted people say it's a quality game and recommend it, as a troll or not, because this is worse than Rob Zombie's '31'. And that movie was terrible. Really, if you want a quality game that still has the room changing mechanic, install Vanish on GameJolt, it's good and free.

												The Hat Man: Shadow Ward is a must-have for gamers who love horror. I feel positively about most aspects of this game. First of all, the price. This game is very affordable at the price of £0.79, although I picked this up in a sale (£0.19!), and it is worth it! I feel this game is quite underappreciated for what it is. The plot of the game itself is interesting, but yet not very unique. A mental asylum is quite common to see in horror games, however, copying ideas can result in a better game overall (the way I feel about this game). In no way at all will I compare this game with other horror survival games such as Outlast or Alien: Isolation, but it must be said, this game is genuinely scary, what you'd look for in a horror game.I feel the way this game's layout is set is great, for example, the beginning of this game has a few doors that I myself thought you'd be able to open, but cannot. This can result in disliking the game or liking it even more. For me, this tactic doesnt mean the map is too detailed, and I like that. Many times I've played games that have had too many places to go to, when in the end, all I had to do was go through the main door. Adding details like doors that canot be opened helps prevent wasting time, which is great, getting to the next point of the story without wasting time or lowering suspense. Like I covered previously, the main obvious plot is not too unique, which isn't necessarily a bad thing at all! Having a man chase you through a mental asylum is, of course, going to be a common theme. (Please note, the actual story to this game is rather unique, and the fact it's based off a real life story makes it all the more scarier!). The controls are easy to use, the game is not too basic nor complicated, and there are plenty of them (and they're rather familiar with other games). Graphics, textures are all fine, and the flow of gameplay compliments it well.Overall, I really enjoyed this game. I appreciate games like these that are affordable, fun to play, not complicated and that give you a few hours of enjoyment. I'd strongly recommend this to people who enjoy horror games.

												The Hat Man: Shadow Ward is an indie horror game, seemingly heavily inspired by Slender and similar games. You play as the father(or mother, depending on which you pick) of a young girl who was sent to an Asylum. You receive a message telling you that your daughter is missing and you decide to go look for her in the Asylum. Upon entering her room and opening her diary the Asylum changes, the diary explodes and the first Shadow person appears. You are now compelled to gather all the pages of the dairy as the games gets progressively harder with each page. Overall, the game is pretty graphically outdated(it's an indie game with a limited budget), but they were able to get the spooks pretty well(the SFX were nice, too). The voice-acting is either purposely bad or just bad, so it kinda makes it hard to get scared when the voice-acting makes you wanna laugh. There are some bugs and the Shadow people are pretty slow and you get rid of them quite easily. One of the biggest issues was the fact that upon dying I was cast back to the beginning, hence I'd recommend a way of saving the game or just more checkpoints. If you wanna get some creepy atmosphere going I suggest buying the game on sale, there are better titles out there, but it's still pretty solid.>I'd give it a 5/10>Pros: Spooky atmosphere, achievements, randomly generated map, allegedly based on real stories.>Cons: Bugs, inability to save/rare checkpoints, the enemies aren't that tough, voice-acting, short, graphics are outdated, the rooms look almost the same but it isn't that bad.Copy supplied by developer.

content:
2015
-Quick Review-The Hat Man: Shadow Ward is an indie "horror" game that adopts many game play features from Slenderman, but expands on them to bring you a some-what-suspenseful-page-collection-puzzle-game, and far more fair to you then Slenderman ever was. -Detailed breakdown review- Story:  You play as either the father or mother searching for their daughter in an insane asylum, after stumbling across your daughters journal, the book is ripped asunder. You now need to puzzle your way through the labyrinth of the asylum and collect pages of your daughters journal and tools to help you progress to the next series of rooms.The voice acting is pretty amusing, it's just the right combination of "expressive" and "emotionless", probably first-time-voice actors. If nothing else you need to play just enough to hear some of the ridicules things they say. "What the...? Now you have my attention" Game Play: As I've already eluded too, the game takes the "page collection" and "being chased by a noisy black figure" from the Slederman series. (I'll stick that in spoiler tags if you're really that sensitive)I haven't played very many horror games so I won't pretend to well versed in the art that is "scaring people", I do know that whenever I play a scary game my whole goal is to keep myself from expressing it. This game succeeded in keeping me in suspense and catching me by surprise a few times.Potential key game play feature spoiler: after you start the game by finding the journal, you need to puzzle you way through a sequence of rooms that will randomly change, however to unlock a new area, you need to use a specific item to progress, such as opening a special door, or moving an obstacle.  Achievements: The achievements are fairly straightforward; finish the game fast (30 minutes is the fastest achievement), finish the game without saving, and then the rest are pretty simple or obvious repeat-to-get-this-achievement.Update: May 24, 2015. Ruh roh, it looks like three of the achievements are bugged, the counters for: Paranormally Active, Cheating Death, and A Good Book are broken and not adding up properly. This maybe fixed someday, but judging from the forums the achievements have been broken since at least May 1st 2015. Price: The Hat Man: Shadow Ward is priced at $4.99, I was gifted my copy by one of the developers (thank you!), the price is pretty fair, considering the effort put into the game. However you probably won't put more than a couple hours into the game. Conclusion: When it comes to Indie games, I tend to prefer to show support for up and budding game developers. This game might be a skip for most people, but it does have promise and takes a few steps in a different direction from the original inspiration.------Edits and updates------Edit/Update May 24, 2015:Update about broken achievements within the game.

Review for The Hat Man: Shadow WardPros Good scary enviroment Amazing sounds to get you scared Game isnt that buggy especially for being an Indie game Randomly generated, different everytimeCons Game doesnt really tell you what to do.  I figured out that you were trying to find pages just from seeing three in the main room Controls are abit weird My pc had weird framerate issues with it  Becomes kind of redundant at times when running through the hallsOverall Review        You play as the parent to your child who has gone missing in an asylum.  You find pages written by your daughter in her journal that has a baby face on it?  After you collect it in the beginning, you set off inside to find more pages.  You then come to realize that you are being followed by the man in the hat (aka the name of the game).  You also realize that the rooms are randomly generated as you go through and even if you go backwards the room that you were in will have been changed as well.  This allows for some interesting adventure to the game but the rooms do get repetative.  There are little jump scares that happen throughout the game though like a ghost girl will faze through the wall or a light will fall on you and play a loud sound.  You also find different items throughout the game like matches will help you overcome later challenges. Overall I would rate this game 8 out 10.Misc stuffI purchased the game for 25 cents when it was on sale.  Though I wouldnt mind buying the game full price because of how much I enjoyed it.  Sure its a "Slender" knock off but the game is randomly generated unlike slender where you walk through the same areas over and over again until you find the pages.  This game is also an Indie game and I would really like to see where it goes.  This is an amazing start for a horror game and I cannot wait to see what the developers will do to make it even bettertl;dr -its a small download-its fun-its scary-it doesnt cost alot-its an Indie game

												Disclosure: received free copy of the game.Shortly described this is a Survival running horror game that has randomized elements as the map is different on every play trough. The hallways even change during the same session if one walks away far enough so it really is random. Difficulty is quite tough and constant restarts actually reminds me of Receiver, a game that is not a horror game but has the same random map every time you play it and similar kind of (illusion) of choices - and both have quite tough difficulty that goes up slowly but surely. I have no idea what people mean when they say in some reviews that this game is a walk in the park - they must mean earlier versions as after some 3 hours i have managed to beat the game only once using save points. So many things CAN and WILL go wrong even after you think you have the mechanics figured out. For me the concept just works. I have a lot of horror games in my library but not a nifty little horror game title like this.  This game will not blow your mind and redefine the horror genre but in my books it doesn't need to. It is enough to preferably bring a new element and solid gameplay and you have a game worth it's price and this the game is able to do. This is not a large game like Penumbra series/Amnesia nor is it a design marvel of a game squeezed into a tight space such as Anna.Cons? Few but there are some. Rough edges here and there are annoying. Clicking on items is best done by clicking franticaly it seems. Beginning of the game is also weakest. For example if the game is so well into randomized hallways then i'd prefer to skip the early pleasantries after awhile. Also ghosts coming trough the floor at you can be a problem when changing floors so stairs require your full attention. I was also killed for the first time before i even got the flashlight. Tiny details like these which dont matter at all after some hours but add to the rough feeling in the first 30minutes. i'd also not see the face of the Hat Man at all during death. Like games better that leave it to players own imagination what happens when you get caught.  (sound can also  be sometimes more effective than visuals)3 hours clocked at this time and will be expecting at least some hours more as i have not yet grown tired of the game. i'd say this is a good addition to the horror library.

												This game isn't for everyone. But it IS based on a true story.IN FACT, my story. I know it sounds like bullgarbage but imagine seeing this without being able to move. It's certainly original by using a real life [disorder?] and expanding it to be a central enemy.Now, I honestly don't play it much out of the fact that I live and suffer this, it's not hallucination, it's waking up paralysed and seeing things. It's across all cultures though most call it Hat Man, Old Hag, or a demon sitting heavily on your chest. I've experienced these with terrifying reality, being that I wake up with a dream state and reality blurred together.Why does this matter.. well it is based on far more than one true story, and takes it to another level. I will probably never play this game a whole lot for fear of triggering worse or other effects. [soon after, I started to wake up and "lag" with a rubberband effect. I woke up 17 times and I had to claw my way out of bed only to finally wake up.]I don't think they can capture the phenomenon and the absolute, crystalline horror. But they did a good job of expanding it into a "full story" and making it playable. From experience they perfectly captured the "inescapable shadow" [most common non-contact think one sees AFAIK.] Buy this game if you suffer from this and hopefully it will be theraputic but most of all buy this game if you want to feel and scratch the surface of a sublimely beautiful condition, that at it's heart, is truly a unique thing and 99% harmless to the average person.Seeing such horror in real life while waking [some while sleeping, but I suffer both sides, mostly waking.] is actually "cool" in my opinion. But the worst part is knowing it's not real, but seeing what you see and the feelings of not breathing and need to escape WILL show you that willpower will not save you.But..I just fear one day I will wake up and it will be all too real.

content:

												The Hat Man: Shadow Ward is an indie horror adventure game. You play as the father or the mother of a girl who has gone missing in an insane asylum. You arrive in the asylum to go looking for her, but there is nobody in the asylum except for a ghostlike creature called the Hat Man. You spend the game running away from the Hat Man and meanwhile collecting two kinds of items:- diary pages written by your daughter, explaining a bit what's going on and what you need to do next- items that help you advance e.g. at the very start there is a barricaded door => you pick up a nearby axe and use it to remove the obstacleThe asylum's hallways and rooms are continuously generated at random. So I didn't really like the fact that you couldn't rely on your memory and orientation skills to find your way in the asylum. You just need to keep running until you come across the item you need to advance to the next part of the asylum. What I did like about 'The Hat Man: Shadow Ward' is that you get a short thrilling experience for nearly no money at all. When I finished the game, I was surprised to see I got the achievement for finishing the game in under half an hour. It seemed longer what with the running around through the endless hallways and what with reloading when caught by the Hat Man. But the game shouldn't have been any longer than it is, because it's too 'basic' to entertain for hours. Now, at the price of this game (and especially when on sale) I think it's certainly worth playing if you're into the horror-atmosphere type games and are willing to settle for a quick, cheap fix.

												As an avid lover of horror games and resident scardey-cat, there's no better combination than a good, old-fashioned, spooky indie horror puzzle game to get the blood pumping. Although the game is quite short and doesn't have the most intricate story line, it manages to maintain a spooky atmosphere throughout the playthrough. The rooms and corridors are somewhat repetitive, but do shuffle themselves around, so back-tracking is simply not that simple. The straightforward design is accentuated by decent graphics and a very eerie atmosphere. Despite collecting (what seems like) hundreds of diary entries from your daughter, very little is actually revealed about the Hat Man, adding to his mysterious allure. The puzzles aren't exactly rocket-science, more of a "find-the-object-and-use-it-on-another-object" type of scenario. Nevertheless, this just adds emphasis on the fact that a creepy shadow fiend is chasing you and you can't spend time strolling around taking pictures and making mental notes of how good the wallpaper would look in your own house.Overall, I would recommend this game, especially if it happens to be on sale. Simple, effective and the voice over is hilariously awkward.Enjoy!

												This is a very very nice example with what kinds of twists and turns people can conjure up while thinking of the original Slender game. The literal PAGES you need to collect, easier to find, mind you (because you're in a building the whole game), being hunted by an also literal 'Hat Man' that becomes more aggressive with the more pages you collect for your journal. There's a short story to it as well, that kind of explain why you're collecting them, and the creatures --the Hat Man and little shadow dudes-- that stalk you and want to stop you from reaching your goal are pretty damn spooky. As I always say with horror games, they're always WAY worse wen you play them for yourself. I'd have more time on this, but it's actually kind of irritating to keep trying to make a good amount of progress in one sitting.Still, though, big support from me ^-^

												When I first began my adventure, into the world of The Hat Man, I wondered why steam was classifying it under s when it clearly started with T. Moving right along, I noticed from the settings menu at the beginning it was probably made in Unity; which gave me bad feels inside. Afterwards I started up the game with the highest settings possible, and the interface looked atrocious, the buttons were all comically oversized and didn't provide enough options; but I digress, I started up the game and was immediately greeted with a five nights at freddys lights sound clip playing on loop; this was to be the most scary event of my adventure.I left the elevator and went up some stairs, went into a room, wandered about it, left it as it wasn't very interesting, explored the rest of the area, went back in the elevator, contemplated suicide, went back into the room and found the silly looking book. The book exploded and I said: "Ok, now you have my attention, suddenly the funroom isn't looking very fun!" in a silly very non-serious voice, so I tried to leave and told myself that I haven't gotten everything yet. I didn't care, I'm not some OCD crackaddict who needs to collect everything, so I grab the flashlight on the table and try again; and to my horror I still have not collected everything. So I start cleaning up the pieces of garbage scattered on the floor thinking: "Hey, maybe I'm a janitor in this game" and suddenly I could leave. Oh also there was a black mage who tried to ambush me, but I slew him with my flashlight some how. So I wondered aimlessly for a while after killing a door with another silly dialogue, and admired all the five nights at freddys lights sound clip playing in every single light in the game.Eventually I got really sick and tired of picking up papers and wandering empty corridors, but I perseveered because why not. So I saw this big guy with a hat floating towards me so I went over to talk to him and made a very girly scream as I stood there looking at him; please note, he did not attack me, but I had a heart attack or I got flung back in time to when I was in the fun house room. So I gathered the flashlight and the papers-But then it happened.. The door. You have not collected everything.I gotten everything, but I couldn't leave, and the black mages kept spawning- until suddenly a black mage spawned who was immune to my flashlight, and then the game locked up, and steam locked up, and I couldn't alt+f4 out of it, and I couldn't minimize out of it, and I said "Good Game" and, since I have a second monitor; I simply closed out of it in task manager. It unfortunately murdered steam along with it and thus I had to relaunch steam just to post this review.I'll give it a 2/10; for the sake of black mages at the very start of the game. Next time use UFPS to manage your first person camera, and get some more original sound clips and make sure the game actually works.I have no idea why this game is even on steam; it's something which would be better off sold for free; I mean come on; Swamp Sim is more scary and entertaining than this.And now, now; I can predict what some of you may be saying; "It's only 19 cents, what do you expect from it?"Just because something is cheap, and you should expect it to suck; does not make it worthy of being considered a good game, or a game that could possibly be recommended.

content:
2015
												You are either the father or mother (you get to choose) of a daughter who has been put into a mental ward for her own safety. The thing is something has happened there, and even though you were told to stay away you have decided to check up on your daughter. That's where things start getting even stranger. You leave the elevator and can't seem to find anyone around. You locate your daughter's room and find a journal with a strange looking face on it. Upon touching it you are transported into the Shadow Ward. The journal's page scatter in a strange wind that pulls through the mental ward when you touch the journal. You will have to collect the pages if you are ever going to find out what has happened to your daughter, and perhaps find a way out of this situation for yourself. You see once you enter the Shadow Ward you will find that you are no longer alone.In The Hat Man: Shadow Ward, you will find that there is a shadow being that goes by the name of the Hat Man. The Hat Man seems to be stalking the halls, and if he catches you you will be paralyze, your soul stolen, and if you wish to try your luck again, you will have to start from scratch.On the outside this looks like a very scary game where there's going to be tons of jump out of your seat scares, and to be honest when the Hat Man catches you, most of the time it will make you jump out of your skin. The only problem is some of the mechanics. When I talk about mechanics I'm talking about several things in the game.The first mechanic is the randomization of the game layout. I'm all for changing things up through each playthrough, but that being the case I feel like this game would have GREATLY benefited from a checkpoint system. The way I would have done it is that you have to collect the pages in groups of five. I do understand that this would probably screw up the random locations of the pages, but I think there is a level of frustration that starts to creep in, especially since the Hat Man's location could literally be in the wall in the room you start your adventure into the Shadow Ward.The second mechanic is the inventory system, maybe it's my computer, but it took an act of God to change items that were currently equipped. Now thankfully you're going to be spending the majority of the time with the flashlight in hand, but it would have been nice if the game would have allowed a smoother transition between items.The third mechanic surrounds the journal pages. Part of what makes this game creepy is what is written in the journal pages, and currently the only way to actually find out what are in the pages you picked up is to go into the journal. Why not just have the audio start to play upon picking up the page so that the player isn't taken out of the game to find out what is on the pages? Oh and if you have to go into the journal to find out what is written on them, the audio should probably match up to ALL entries. There's at least one case that I can think of off the top of my head where the page had something other than what was being said to me.The thing is this game has that spookiness to it that will keep people on edge, but with just enough randomness to cause people to get frustrated. I know its a race against time as you try to stay 2 steps in front of the Hat Man as you try to recover all the journal pages, but when his location seems to be randomized, and the first playthrough I met my demise without ever really getting into the game, it kind of kills the want to play again.I'm going to be totally honest, I have yet to fully complete the game, but it isn't from a lack of trying. The only way that I've been able to get anywhere in this game is from constantly sprinting through the entire game, and listening for the whispers, that's when you know you are close to another journal page. I appreciate that there are items hidden in the game that cause you to have to really search the area, but without a map to refer to and the fact that you have to stay constantly on the run, there's a really good chance that a player could be doing a large loop over and over again not knowing what to do, scared that if they slow down and start to really investigate the Hat Man will appear, and you'll have to start all over again.So here's the deal, this game has its moments, and I think it is possible, if all the stars align that this could be the experience that I think the developers are hoping the player gets, but with all the random variables, and the fact that the Hat Man can strike right off the bat, this game is too much of a game of chance to really enjoy. This game gets a 6.2 out of 10.

												The Hat Man: Shadow Ward... Basically a worse Slender game with more pages, and a slight advantage when collecting them.~~~Story:You can play as the mother or father of a girl, Virginia Berry, who was put in an insane asylum for attempting suicide. Virginia has gone missing, and you go a look for her. You pick up her journal, and it 'corrupts' you, and you must collect all 22 pages, and a few other items to save your daughter before the 'Shadow People' get you and capture your soul. As you collect the pages, it tells you a story of her reading the book about the HatMan after a woman told her to. She wasn't sure why, but she did.~~~A little Canton Insane Asylum background: Canton's Asylum is located in West Virginia in the United States. Congress has passes a bill creating the only 'Institution of Insane Indians' in the US. (So, I'm guess this family was Indian. [That's beside the point.]) It was opened in January 1903, this asylum was also sometimes called Hiawatha Insane Asylum. Many inmates put here were not mentally ill. The asylum closed in 1934. Atleast 121 died, and more than 350 patients were detained here.Flaws:-TV's were not invented until the 1927's. So I don't think that the TV's with static were a good placement for this time period.-I think if the developers did a little research on the place and time era, they could have made a better plot, giving an more intreaging story, and a better experience.~~~Sound:The sounds were hilarious for this game. The voice overs for the daughter, mother, and father, and the Hat Man. The Hat Man, when he takes you is the best noise in this game. (I'm kidding, it's also really bad.)To be honest, I actually like the music from the music players. They are not too bad.The pages make a whispering noise that is very obnoxious, and annoying. Maybe not to others, but to me, I did not like the noises for them.-If more time was put into the sound, it could have helped enchance the game play, and actually make this is a scary game.~~~Challenge:This game really isn't challenging... wait. Why can't I pick up my axe again after I used it? Okay...~~~I wouldn't recommend this game. The play time is short, and not very interesting to me. I would not replay it after I beat it, which I won't beat.-I haven't finished the game. I've given up trying to figure out this hell hole.Rates:Story: 4Challenge: 3Sound: 4Replayability: 1Enjoyment: 4Frustration: 3

Upon touching it you are transported into the Shadow Ward. The journal's page scatter in a strange wind that pulls through the mental ward when you touch the journal. You will have to collect the pages if you are ever going to find out what has happened to your daughter, and perhaps find a way out of this situation for yourself. You see once you enter the Shadow Ward you will find that you are no longer alone.In The Hat Man: Shadow Ward, you will find that there is a shadow being that goes by the name of the Hat Man. The Hat Man seems to be stalking the halls, and if he catches you you will be paralyze, your soul stolen, and if you wish to try your luck again, you will have to start from scratch.On the outside this looks like a very scary game where there's going to be tons of jump out of your seat scares, and to be honest when the Hat Man catches you, most of the time it will make you jump out of your skin. The only problem is some of the mechanics. When I talk about mechanics I'm talking about several things in the game.The first mechanic is the randomization of the game layout. I'm all for changing things up through each playthrough, but that being the case I feel like this game would have GREATLY benefited from a checkpoint system. The way I would have done it is that you have to collect the pages in groups of five. I do understand that this would probably screw up the random locations of the pages, but I think there is a level of frustration that starts to creep in, especially since the Hat Man's location could literally be in the wall in the room you start your adventure into the Shadow Ward.The second mechanic is the inventory system, maybe it's my computer, but it took an act of God to change items that were currently equipped. Now thankfully you're going to be spending the majority of the time with the flashlight in hand, but it would have been nice if the game would have allowed a smoother transition between items.The third mechanic surrounds the journal pages. Part of what makes this game creepy is what is written in the journal pages, and currently the only way to actually find out what are in the pages you picked up is to go into the journal. Why not just have the audio start to play upon picking up the page so that the player isn't taken out of the game to find out what is on the pages? Oh and if you have to go into the journal to find out what is written on them, the audio should probably match up to ALL entries. There's at least one case that I can think of off the top of my head where the page had something other than what was being said to me.The thing is this game has that spookiness to it that will keep people on edge, but with just enough randomness to cause people to get frustrated. I know its a race against time as you try to stay 2 steps in front of the Hat Man as you try to recover all the journal pages, but when his location seems to be randomized, and the first playthrough I met my demise without ever really getting into the game, it kind of kills the want to play again.I'm going to be totally honest, I have yet to fully complete the game, but it isn't from a lack of trying. The only way that I've been able to get anywhere in this game is from constantly sprinting through the entire game, and listening for the whispers, that's when you know you are close to another journal page. I appreciate that there are items hidden in the game that cause you to have to really search the area, but without a map to refer to and the fact that you have to stay constantly on the run, there's a really good chance that a player could be doing a large loop over and over again not knowing what to do, scared that if they slow down and start to really investigate the Hat Man will appear, and you'll have to start all over again.So here's the deal, this game has its moments, and I think it is possible, if all the stars align that this could be the experience that I think the developers are hoping the player gets, but with all the random variables, and the fact that the Hat Man can strike right off the bat, this game is too much of a game of chance to really enjoy. This game gets a 6.2 out of 10.

er 14, 2015
												This game is creepy and mean. I think the game should save everytime you find a page, but alas you cannot save your game until you find a TV (I read) so everytime the shadow people or hat man get you, and trust me, THEY WILL GET YOU, you have to start all over! Whether flashlight is on or off they can still find you and hiding is a recipe for disaster, only thing you can do is hope to outrun them and even then if they are too close they can pass through a wall and still get you no matter how quickly you move. Good news is you CAN sprint! Uhm...great story so far. I have never played Slender yet, but I hear this game is a lot like that. You explore a Silent Hill-esque asylum looking for useful items and pages which are clues to the unfolding story. You can kill shadow people with the flashlight, but you CANNOT kill the Hat Man until end game.10/10 Scary Voices = Good 10/10 Heavy Breathing = Good10/10 Heart Beats = Bad-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------A shadow person (also known as a shadow figure, shadow being or black mass) is the perception of a patch of shadow as a living, humanoid figure, particularly as interpreted by believers in the paranormal or supernatural as the presence of a spirit or other entity. Many methamphetamine addicts report hallucinations of "shadow people", as a result of sleep deprivation.A number of religions, legends, and belief systems describe shadowy spiritual beings or supernatural entities such as shades of the underworld, and various shadowy creatures have long been a staple of folklore and ghost stories.Although participants in online discussion forums devoted to paranormal and supernatural topics describe them as menacing, other believers and paranormal authors do not agree whether shadow people are either evil, helpful, or neutral, and some even speculate that shadow people may be the extra-dimensional inhabitants of another universe. Some paranormal investigators and authors such as Chad Stambaugh claim to have recorded images of shadow people on video.Several physiological and psychological conditions can account for reported experiences of shadowy shapes seeming alive. A sleep paralysis sufferer may perceive a "shadowy or indistinct shape" approaching them when they awake paralysed, and become increasingly alarmed. A person experiencing heightened emotion, such as while walking alone on a dark night, may incorrectly perceive a patch of shadow as an attacker.Many methamphetamine addicts report the appearance of "shadow people" after prolonged periods of sleep deprivation. Psychiatrist Jack Potts suggests that methamphetamine usage adds a "conspiratorial component" to the sleep deprivation hallucinations. One interviewed subject said that "You don't see shadow dogs or shadow birds or shadow cars. You see shadow people. Standing in doorways, walking behind you, coming at you on the sidewalk. These hallucinations have been directly compared to the paranormal entities described in folklore.The explanation we get from skeptics and mainstream science - and who are usually people who have never experienced the shadow people phenomenon - is that it is nothing more than the active human imagination. It's our minds playing tricks on us... our eyes seeing things in a fraction of a second that aren't really there - illusions...real shadows caused by passing auto headlights, or some similar explanation. And without a doubt, these explanations probably can account for some if not many experiences. The human eye and mind are easily fooled. But can they account for all cases?To call these entities ghosts demands first a definition of what we mean by ghosts.But by almost any definition, shadow people are somewhat different than ghost phenomena. Whereas ghost apparitions are almost always a misty white, vapor-like or have a decidedly human form and appearance (very often with discernible "clothing"), shadow beings are much darker and more shadow-like. In general, although the shadow people often do have a human outline or shape, because they are dark, the details of their appearance is lacking. This is in contrast to many ghost sightings in which the witness can describe the ghost's facial features, style of clothing and other details. The one detail most often noted in some shadow being sightings are their glowing red eyes.The dark countenance and malevolent feelings that are often reported in association with these creatures has led some researchers to speculate that they may be demonic in nature. If they are demons, we have to wonder what their purpose or intent is in letting themselves be seen in this manner. Is it merely to frighten?One interesting idea suggests that shadow people are the shadows or essences of people who are having out-of-body experiences. According to Jerry Gross, an author, lecturer and teacher about astral travel, we all travel out of the body when we are asleep. Perhaps, this theory says, we are seeing the ephemeral astral bodies of these twilight travelers.People from our own future, another idea states, could have found the means to travel to the past - our time. However they are able to accomplish this incredible feat, perhaps in that state they appear to us merely as passing shadows as they observe the events of our timeline.Even mainstream science is fairly convinced that there are dimensions other than the three we inhabit. And if these other dimensions exist, who or what (if anything) inhabits them?-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------I recommend this game for the experience, however, I will probably never finish it or play it largely based on the highly unfair mechanics. For example, every time I happen apon a certain part of the asylum where there is a large hole in the floor, the Hat Man always appears behind me and there is nowhere to run to. You can either jump to your death down into the hole or have your soul devoured by Hat Man. I consider that a gamebreaking bug. I hope the Dev will add places to hide from Hat Man, or create a device that can at least temporarily freeze him, something exhaustible so you can only use it so many times, or once and such items are randomly placed, but rare. I would like to see more variety of rooms or even randomized rooms as one poster in the forums suggested. The game can be expanded with a few doors that need unlocked and a key may be found. More props and assets to decor rooms and hallways. More gore! More scares and weird Lovecraftian notes to read which possibly shed light on the Shadow People phenomena similar to such info I pasted here from wikipedia. A few more checkpoints in the game. Maybe game saves, if not with each page pick up, but maybe with those special "key" items like matches, crowbar, etc. This game is amazing, but currently 'replayablity' is a huge issue since, well, basically you have no choice at present. -----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------TL;DR: RUN!

Mostly is about things chasing you and putting pressure on you to escape or die. Guess that is some kind of a "horror experience", but games like this are not my cup of tea: too much running around a maze of halls and rooms almost identical and often getting lost searching for little things to advance, there's no map nor any way to be sure you went already into some place and that gets annoying fast to me... but totally can expect other players to have fun with Hat Man, others with a better sense of orientation than me, that is. Anyway, I recommend if you're not expecting much, cause there ain't much besides that scary thing coming at you. Nevertheless, a little dose of adrenaline is at times worth the time and the dime.

number of helpful: 3 of 5 people (60%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
21, 2015
												The Hat Man: Shadow Ward is a horror game that sends you off in a hospital hell to collect journal pages and overcome obstacles in an attempt to bring your daughter home. Using a simple search-and-find-the-pages mechanic used in other very famous horror games, The Hat Man also adds the twist of having a changing maze inside the asylum so that one hallway isn't always the one you just came from. You're fleeing The Hat Man, a paranormal anomaly called a shadow person, who feeds upon the sick and weak. Did I mention he can teleport? He does that.A lot.God I'm gonna steal that stupid hat and throw it down the hall and see if that'll distract him. I digress.The game isn't difficult. Notes are shrouded in whispers so as you find yourself outside a room containing one, the whispers within your head becoming maddening (they might even drive you...insane? RIMSHOT.) Your foe moves slowly enough that you can out run him or you can hide if you find a perfect method of how to do it. Rooms are spacious that if you plan things, you can loop around to bypass the hovering spectre. That is, if you're quick about it. I didn't have so much luck with this. I ended up rushing into walls and getting caught just by that last second and ended up starting over. Sigh.As this is a horror game, you're probably asking just how scary is it. Shadow people, as we know them, tend to be these looming types that are said to stand there and make you feel uncomfortable. The Hat Man is designed well enough that he gives you a you a nice shock when he teleports right into your face in a very literal way. One second you've left him five hallways away and POOF, there he is! You can also see him coming from a good distance off so you're feeling pretty free to give him the finger. He's not gruesome, but just unsettling enough that he reinforces the stories of shadow people being vague, smoky, and shadowy outlines of people who are unable to take proper forms. He's a bit menacing so that was good enough for me. Good enough for me to swear every time he tried to tickle me with those ugly hands.As for the feel of the game, I mentioned it's a good hospital hell. You've got rotting bodies, the sound of people crisping against defibs (I jumped a foot), the traditional falling ceiling tiles, loud noises to freak you out as you turn corners, and the much appreciated radio playing assorted music. I loved the pieces that made me feel like it was a Twilight Zone episode. The radio is a nice touch. It's something a lot of games do, but not many use them so nicely as this, I believe.You can play as the father or mother. This has no bearing on the story. Your child's sarcasm and dull humor as noted in the diary OBVIOUSLY comes from your commentary. You are a parent on a mission and somehow you even make some off-color comments at the start of this adventure. (Father calls the asylum a funhouse. Mother says homemaker turned homewrecker.) Upon reading the journal, even your daughter has found time to make off-color comments about her own situation. The apple has not fallen far from the tree. This amused me greatly. I didn't find it out of character at all. It seems like a perfect defense mechanism in a horrible time like that. (Referring to her attempts as a "been there, done that" light heartedly in group therapy which horrifies everyone who has never attempted? Yes as someone who has been there, I find this very funny.)Overall, the game is one that's simple in premise and offers gameplay that a majority can enjoy. However, I noticed a few things that did make my gameplay a little less enjoyable.Upon playing, the save function that was hinted to was not obvious to me. There was no button or indication of an autosave. Even after accomplishing a set of actions where the Hat Man was unable to get me (and I kept mercilessly taunting him until I got stuck in another maze ahaha don't do this.), there was no save function that appeared. Unfortunately, I'm a handicapped gamer and I do need breaks after hitting buttons for a while. I'm just confused if I'm missing something. I did search the forums and I wonder if only I'm missing it. This made the game entirely difficult for me and made me lose interest greatly.The mother's subtitles have a few typos. I noticed. It didn't really kill the game for me but I spotted them.The journal's audio seems a bit off. Is that audio that was placed there that we're not supposed to hear? That doesn't sound like the daughter's normal voice-over. Nothing game killing here, either.Notes for the handicapped gamers like myself: You're going to get tired while navigating. Pause frequently. Take breaks. I'm paused right now, matter of fact. There are flickering lights and flashes. If you are triggered by flashing lights at all, I would exercise extreme caution with this game. I would go as far to say this is not a good idea and play at your own risk.The story is rather unique and I'm happy to see someone use shadow people as a source of horror fuel as they're one of the most common paranormal occurrences in the world. It's a little bare bones and maybe even cliched, but it does well enough. The world of the "limbo asylum" is rough yet rather beautiful. You're not getting AAA graphics because after all, it's an indie horror, but it's pretty enough to know that even if the world you're traversing in does repeat in a maze of horror, there was some time taken to make sure that everything looked properly decrepit and set out. Though large hospital rooms seem more for gameplay benefit rather than realism. You will be kissing the ground for those large rooms.This game reaches a wide audience. There are those who like medical horror in their video games, those who enjoy the collect-and-boo type horror games, those who enjoy chase-type games, and those who are constantly in the need of challenging themselves to beat their time. Trust me. You'll want to tackle the achievements to beat Hat Boy in record time.

												Page collector 2014.This is not a terrible game.  It just is not a great game.  It is an average game that I found boring.The game is made in Unity.  You can play as either the father or the mother searching for their lost daughter in the insane asylum.  There are voice overs, and the acting is competent.   It isn't terrible, but it isn't outstanding.  Like everything in this game.As mentioned, the game is in Unity.  The engine is smooth.  The graphics are not outstanding, but it animates well.  Moving your character is intuitive, although I found the movement a little awkward at times.  When there is something you can interact with a little hand will appear, and that is when you click.The entire game, however, is just a search for pages of your daughters diary.  There are a few mild scares, and the setting in general tries to be unsettling.  Walking around a generic assylum that was dark looking for paper.... well, it just got boring.If the game is on sale and you have some time to kill for a very average horror experience, pick it up.  Otherwise there are better ways to spend your gaming time.5/10

												Hat Man: Shadow ward takes place in an Asylum, you will play either as the Father or the Mother of a young girl that tried to commit suicide, which caused her to be assigned in a mental asylum for the insane in hopes that she does not do anything to further harm herself. When you first start the game, you are greeted with a note saying that she has somehow "Gone Missing". When you exit the elevator, everything will look just fine except for the fact that it's completely devoid of life. But as soon you will find a cursed book which will cause everything to change. The once normal looking asylum will reveal it's true state, a rotting and decrepit mess. Grab your flashlight and start collecting 22 pages in a way similar to slenderman! This is based on true stories and sightings of the one that we call "The Hat Man". He, along with his shadow people will try and get you so they can take your soul. The game relies heavily on the sound and atmosphere, keeping you on your heels from the start, the only thing i can reccomend is if you see "The Hat Man" just run, run and don't look back. When your lights flicker, then your problem is just starting, friend. Get out as soon as possible. Whispers will tell you that there is a page nearby. The Hat Man and his lackeys aren't the only thing you have to worry about though, there are other ways to die too! There's an eastern egg featuring everyone who helped this game be realised, as well as the devs near the start (if you're interested). The voice-acting isn't the best, but it's just a fresh company, we can't really expect much. The graphics are also not bad. The game is still good though. Hopefully this will be one of many to come!

content:
30, 2015
												Prepare to die screaming…or more likely laughing at the horrendously bad voice acting of ‘The Hat Man: The 20+ Pages’……wait….wrong game (and more on the voice acting later). Alas, just as has happened with so many other indie horror games in recent years and with the advent of the Slender series, ‘The Hat Man: Shadow Ward’ (the ‘for real’ name) falls victim to the same ‘collect quest’ gameplay mechanic. This means that you need to find a set number of pages from your daughter’s diary to complete the game. Ultimately, that’s the basis of the game: you either play as the father or mother in search of said daughter, who has gone missing from the seemingly empty asylum she was committed to which is now populated by shadow people/The Hat Man (BTW – the idea of shadow peeps is based loosely on fact and there are many documented cases, and even some decent movies, about people that have seen or had encounters with these so-called ‘Shadow People’). Thankfully, you don’t just search for pages as you also need to find some other items to progress deeper into the asylum and defeat The Hat Man (who I guess is like the pimp of the shadow peeps) to get your daughter back.One of the more unique attributes of this game (though it’s been done before) is that sound is utilized to pinpoint the location of pages/other items you need by means of whispery voices. Also, the sound design of this game isn’t half bad for being a budget title, with some of the sound effects/ambient music being pretty creepy in my opinion. Now as promised, I must go back to my earlier comment about the voice acting. Granted, this game is super short and can be beat in less than half an hour, so you may think that voice acting wouldn’t be too important in such a game…..but it kinda, sorta totally is. Essentially, it’s hilarious. No, seriously, I’m not joking. I mean, it’s so stupendously bad that it’s good (I don’t know how that works; it defies the human intellect to comprehend how that can be) but it’s true. I figure most people will laugh at it, though some may actually want to cry at how bad it is. And for all those 100% achievement unlock Steamers out there – prepare thine selves!! There is actually an achievement for listening to your daughter reading the pages of her diary as you collect them. Sure, this game can fairly easily be ‘100%’d’ and the aforementioned achievement is easy enough to unlock, but don’t go joy-puking your faces off just yet as I seriously believe that listening to all of the pages may very well land you in an asylum. I personally just barely managed to keep my sanity intact while unlocking this achievement, so don’t say I didn’t warn you.This game can be fun for like 2 hrs tops, but I wouldn’t recommend it at full price, even if it is a budget title. With decent voice acting, who knows, perhaps this game could have been terrifying. As it is, it will likely be overlooked by most gamers, but it is somewhat interesting and good for a laugh….or cry, so give it a shot.

												Probably the worst horror game I've ever played. Reasons below:-No tutorial. When an enemy comes up to you to eat your face off, you're supposed to defeat it with the flashlight somehow, but the game doesn't mention how.-Unplayably difficult. You need to find twenty-something pages to get anywhere, and around every corner is another shadow person or the Scat Man (sorry, did I say Scat Man? I meant Hat Man). Also, any time he gets you, you go back to the beginning of the game and have to find all those pages again.-It has save points, but they are so scarce and far between that they're nigh nonexistent.-It has a graphics quality bar that changes literally nothing.-The only scary thing about this game is how awful it is. The Hat Man is about as scary as a hangnail. The Shadow People, even less.-Blatant Slender ripoff. Find pages while a shadowy entity chases you... Uh-huh. Doesn't sound familiar at all.Save your 50 cents. Go play Slender: The Arrival instead if you're seeking something similar that will actually scare.

												NOTE: THIS REVIEW IS TO BE UPDATED SOONTo start this Review off I will have a detailed paragraph of the Pros and Cons I have experienced so far with a simple list of pros and cons in case no one wants to read at the bottom. Now, While this is a indie horror game so many people expect a lot of work of developer/publishers for the Genre, The Hat Man does not fail to deliver a interesting game. The one thing I'd like to note is, that I have the exact same feeling of constant dread that I had when playing Alien: Isolation by Sega. Another Pro is that Story isnt THAT bad, and I'm usually more focused on story then anything else. Now, as the store page states, The Hat Man and Shadow People are based on Real Life Stories, Which is true and as something to do i decided to look up the actual Hat Man to compare to the Model the game has. While i couldnt find that great of a image i did compare the two and it does look accurate enough. Also, while Graphics arent state of the art CGI, Its not bad for a small company. Now for the Cons. The Voice Acting needs work but i do give them credit for even having voices. Some physics need work. The last thing i can think of is im not that sure of what is my goal in the game, like am i supposed to collect all the Pages of my daughters Journal without the Hat Man getting me like Slender or is it where i have to find a specific room or what? Anyways this is the end of the paragraph, The rest is the list of Pros and Cons.PROS:*Story*Graphics to a degree*Models*The Atmosphere with the Constant DreadCONS*Goal*Voice Acting*Physics to a DegreeThank you for reading this Review and have a nice day
