r 26, 2014
												Playing this game from the begginign and even through the updates, it has been a dissapointment. The over all story isn't bad, it still needs a lot of work, but the main problems are this; its pretty much just another slenderman-styled game in terms of objective and enemies, the graphics are not that great, it is way too predictable, the hatman himself is a poor adversary and too slow, even in the updates, and he is not scary. In fact the hatman looks like a darker version of the Hatbox Ghost from Disney's Haunted Mansion. It would have been much wiser to replace the tophat with a fedora and made him look like the infamous shadow man seen throughout man decades by many people. I do not recomend getting this game unless it is given out for free or it is sold for at least $0.99. One would be better off buying a slenderman game and playing it for the slenderman would be far scarier and more panic inducing. Developers of this game, I appreciate the effort to bring in a new character to the horror game scene, but you just made remade the same game that we all have been playing for far too long.

												This game has given me a newfound respect for help desk workers that are employed in abandoned asylums. After finding the journal and doing other stuff, I took it upon myself to be stationed behind what I assumed to be the customer service counter on the main floor, as I didn't want other distraught parents to be without aid in the event of their arriving to investigate the absence of their special little flesh spawns. After 5 minutes of waiting, I ultimately got bored and quit, as there was nothing else to do, and no other story to follow or objectives to complete. I guess there was this ghost blob thing too that was really upset by my presence, which is understandable as I had barged in without calling or knocking. I just shined my light in his eyes and expected him to welcome me without quarrel. Overall, This game is an eyeopener, and has a much deeper meaning than what is advertised. 10/10 I got carried away with this review, but am going to post it anyways.

y 8, 2016
												The Hat Man: Shadow Ward is best described as "more okay than I expected." In a time where first-person horror games get dumped out left and right for a shot at YouTube viral status and a quick buck, I didn't expect more than a reskinned Slender-esque with a few cheap deaths. The Hat Man is still a re-skinned Slender-esque, but the reskin isn't too ugly, and the cheap deaths were mostly lacking.In fact, the titular Hat Man is barely effective as a threat at all. He's so easy to hear and avoid that it's highly unlikely you'll run into him in a game-ending sense more than two or three times over the course of the entire game. The bulk of gameplay consists of scrounging around for journal pages and other items as you try to track down your daughter, who's disappeared from her room shortly before your arrival and a sudden turn of everything for the spooky.The asylum that serves as the game's setting is fairly easy to navigate, but suffers from a lot of repetitive textures and room layouts, making getting lost a frequent concern. Eventually things shift to more of a basement, which suffers the same problem, and it's not difficult to miss some of the pages you need upon first pass. It's still not incredibly hard, but when you do have to backtrack despite thinking you've checked every possible room, it gets frustrating very quickly.Aside from the daughter's journey, as spelled out in her journal, the reasons for what you're doing as her parent (you can choose mother or father at the start) are less clearly explained. Storytelling definitely falls short outside those journal bits, which are handily voice-acted so you don't have to read them yourself. Quick tip: Don't turn on the auto-reading of the entries, but listen manually each time, as the former seems not to pop the "listen to every entry" achievement.My final verdict is that The Hat Man: Shadow Ward is mediocre at best. While I didn't hate it, I don't see why I'd suggest anyone else take it for a spin. At least it was really short.

content:
2015
												The poor man's  Slender  (which I also didn't like).Run through dark rooms that look almost exactly like every other room in the game. Avoid the fairly cheesy-looking villain as he chases you through walls (or gets stuck in a doorway, which I've seen happen twice now). Collect missing pages from a book. Try to figure out how in the hell to save your game. (There's apparently an option for it, but damn if I know how it works). Die, and start over again from the beginning. Turn off, and go do something else.I don't want to be overly cruel -- the devs did a good job with the sound effects, and were somewhat successful in inducing nervousness in the player through the "stalker" nature of the villain rather than through cheap jump scares. But the repetitiveness of the environment design and the lack of a reliable save feature eventually make the game too tedious to devote much time to. I might give this another shot someday, but for now it's going back on the shelf. Update: I've tried replaying this turd on and off again over the course of a year, and every time, I find it to be a tedious slog that depends more on procedurally-generated luck than actual skill. And I still have no idea how to save the game. Permanently deleting.

y 8, 2016
												The Hat Man: Shadow Ward is best described as "more okay than I expected." In a time where first-person horror games get dumped out left and right for a shot at YouTube viral status and a quick buck, I didn't expect more than a reskinned Slender-esque with a few cheap deaths. The Hat Man is still a re-skinned Slender-esque, but the reskin isn't too ugly, and the cheap deaths were mostly lacking.In fact, the titular Hat Man is barely effective as a threat at all. He's so easy to hear and avoid that it's highly unlikely you'll run into him in a game-ending sense more than two or three times over the course of the entire game. The bulk of gameplay consists of scrounging around for journal pages and other items as you try to track down your daughter, who's disappeared from her room shortly before your arrival and a sudden turn of everything for the spooky.The asylum that serves as the game's setting is fairly easy to navigate, but suffers from a lot of repetitive textures and room layouts, making getting lost a frequent concern. Eventually things shift to more of a basement, which suffers the same problem, and it's not difficult to miss some of the pages you need upon first pass. It's still not incredibly hard, but when you do have to backtrack despite thinking you've checked every possible room, it gets frustrating very quickly.Aside from the daughter's journey, as spelled out in her journal, the reasons for what you're doing as her parent (you can choose mother or father at the start) are less clearly explained. Storytelling definitely falls short outside those journal bits, which are handily voice-acted so you don't have to read them yourself. Quick tip: Don't turn on the auto-reading of the entries, but listen manually each time, as the former seems not to pop the "listen to every entry" achievement.My final verdict is that The Hat Man: Shadow Ward is mediocre at best. While I didn't hate it, I don't see why I'd suggest anyone else take it for a spin. At least it was really short.

												On sale for $0.19, so well worth it to try it out, but I'm gonna have to give this a No.  I love giving horror games a fighting chance since I'm one for jump-scares and usually people giving reviews call those out as a negative thing.  As far as being scary, this game does an okay job.  The feeling of vulnerability with no weapon and the ability to lose the game by getting "caught" is a little nerve-racking, but otherwise, this game isn't quite there.The weapon you DO get is immediately used up.  You can't pick it up after you use it, which I find weird since it doesn't look hard to pick back up if it were real life.The Journal Pages you need to collect don't add much to the spookiness of it, and are slightly broken.  You get some voice-over for the Journal pages, but some of the pages have text and voiceover that don't match, like the voice is for a completely different page, crushing the illusion.You don't really know where to go and just hope you're going in the right direction.  No maps or anything.  This would be fine, but the scenery you get lost in is repetative, so it gets old after a while.Clicking to open things seemed un-respsonsive.  "Click to Open" with a hand icon on the screen, but clicking doesn't do anything unless you click like nine times.When you first get the ability to scare away shadows, it's creepy and works well.  When you encounter the Hat Man, however, you get the impression that it's supposed to work, but ends up failing, making you move too slowly to get away.I DID like how it stops you if you "miss something".  The game actually says "You missed something" if you don't pick up a vital item, which I thought was a nifty touch.Anyway, like I said, not a loss at all for 19 cents, but that's where I'd draw the line.

r 30, 2015
												Saw this game on sale for 19¢ and saw the game had generally positive reviews on Steam, so I decided to give it a shot.Graphics: D-. The first thing that stood out for me was how bad the graphics are. We're talking PS2-era graphics here, complete with low resution textures, poor lighting, the whole bit. It doesn't seem like a lot of effort was put into them. Especially with subtitles that use a basic Arial font with no style added to them whatsoever. But, graphics like these are typical in most Unity-based games and they did the job I guess.Sound: B+. Apart from the sound effect when picking up items (that sounds like someone hitting a Quarter against an empty bottle of Coke), the sound effects & music were both well done.Story: C-. Nothing fancy here, I won't go too far into it because of spoilers.Gameplay: C+. Apart from the first room which teaches you how to look for items (by listening for them), there is no other tutorial so to speak. The objective is to find all the pages to your Daughter's lost journal and to solve puzzles using certain items to get past obstructions. The rooms are randomly generated so there is no map, while this may make it confusing it ultimately doesn't matter, the game still progresses in linear fashion. I haven't quite figured out how to avoid Hat Man, but you'll know if he's close by when the screen flickers, your heart starts pounding, and the wind nearby sounds all distorted. As for scariness, I personally did not get too spooked even when getting caught my first time. In fact I was more ♥♥♥♥♥♥ off than anything. Results may vary for others, but for me it just didn't freak me out at all. Overall the game can be completed fairly quicky once you find out what to do (I suggest reading a walkthrough, it helps).Performance: C. It's a unity game, so don't expect too many graphical issues like low framerate or glitches. I'm pretty sure just about any PC made after 2003 would be able to run it smoothly. The movement controls are fine, but using items and performing actions seem to have a considerable lag. There were times where left-clicking a door to open it took several times for it to work.Presentation: F. As with the issues with the graphics I mentioned earlier, It doesn't seem like a lot of effort was put into this game. Although it looks like a considerable amount of people worked on this game according to the credits, this game feels like something a dev team of 3-5 people could've made in about a month. Also, it seems like most of the achievements are broken and unobtainable due to bugs. Forum members brought this up back in May 2015 and they have not been addressed as of October. So it seems like support this game has been abandoned.Overall this game is barely worth it at 19 cents and I definitely would not recommend paying full price for this title.

												Well the dev added me and gave me this for free so I feel like I should be nice and give him a good review on this but I also want to be honest because this is one of the worst games I have played in a long time. Before I say anything else I can definitely say that I fully appreciate the time and talent of the people who make games, good or bad, because it isn't easy. To the game's credit it had no technical issues and controlled and performed very smoothly. There is no in-game vsync so I had to force it through Nvidia control panel, but no biggie. Unless I missed it, there is also no mouse sensitivity option so I had to lower it in my razer synapse but also no big deal. Although I am not a fan of adventure games I felt like I owed it to this guy to try his game and give it my honest opinion. The game lacks heavily in detail (basically none) and overall production value. The graphics are a major turn off. The game was very, very bland and very boring. The graphics look like pre Half-Life 1 and the environment is almost empty, only adorned with a few tables and a radio, a few beds in some rooms, sinks and toilets, a few things on the walls, and nothing else. It is very plain and mostly empty. I think the game repeats on itself, meaning there was no end as I moved in a direction through doors and hallways and the environment kept repeating. A piece of ceiling fell down with a scary music que eventually so I guess if you wander enough more things happen. Really though I'm not sure. Three times I encountered a black ghost (Bill Cosby from Ghost Dad I think) with a BOO! cartoon halloween style face and the game just popped up the dead menu, showing restart and quit. Nothing happened, just dead and menu screen. I do not know how the black figure is triggered, or why, or how to avoid him if I see him, or what the point of the game is or what exactly I am supposed to be doing, and overall don't care to see the answer to any of those inquiries. Note: I read that you just go around and collect journal pages and avoid the black figure and the game can be beat in like 30 minutes. That could have saved me a lot of words in my review.Out of 50+ installed games, this game just can't hold an audience with me anymore. 20 minutes was more than enough time spent on this. Although I dislike adventure games, I have played a few out there that are similarly priced (when on sale which is often if you know where to look) that are far superior in every aspect. Namely Outlast. Where this game would be a 3/10 Outlast would be a 8/10, easily trumping this game in every possible aspect.This game is so depressingly void of any real substance in terms of graphics/visual content and gameplay that it is what truly makes it scary. Imagine the inside of a cardboard box with a few miniature doll house chairs and tables and beds set up in it and that is what this game looks like.Thanks for the game. Sorry that it completely blows!

Thank you to the senpai studios for the free review copy.We live in an awesome time where small teams (and in many cases, one person) can create indie games and share them with the world. I love indie games. The Hat Man: Shadow Ward is obviously a labor of love for senpai studios, and I highly encourage them to keep doing what they are doing. There is alot of promise in this work, but unfortunately, I cannot recommend this game. What I can offer is some constructive critiscm. 1. While there are minute differences, it shares all too much with the Slenderman series. I fault that series for the same things found here - the mechanic it is built on is too simple, and the gimmick wears off quickly. That game concept works best as phone or tablet games. To explain further - finding book pages while avoiding a ghost is boring. Maybe if you added RPG-like elements and extended gameplay? Criticism should always be supported with possible options for a fix, IMO.2. Graphics are bland, at best. If you cannot make it hyper-realistic, I would try to go for a retro look. What you have here is something that falls in the middle, and ultimately just looks like every other basic FPS game. I would bet this was made in some GML or game making program (I don't believe senpai studios actually built those wheelchairs sprite by sprite). Once again, I am just trying to seed ideas.3. Maybe get rid of the voice acting, and just add captions.4. Make the Hat Man scarier, and much faster. Maybe make his 'darkness' totally creep and cover your entire view. As-is, he feels like a polygon on a rail.5. I would do something risky - everything that is currently in this game has been done before. In many cases, it has been done better before. Maybe add split-screen co-op where the second player plays as the Hat Man. Might make for a good couch co-op romp. Who knows?Thank you for reading the above ideas, and thank you again to senpai studios for the free copy. I seriously commend you for seeing the complete developemental process to finish. Not many can actually do that. Keep up the hard work. For my Steam friends - pass on this one. Peace,-Ryan

												I know this game is cheap, but that fact doesnt mean that the developer should not try to make it right. After 100 min of playthrough i did find only one bug which was just a minor problem ( in the beginning of the game i couldnt pick up the diary from the floor for no apparent reason, restart fixed it ), but the problem is somewhere else.You are basicaly a parent who is looking for his/her ( you can play for mother or father ) daughter in a mental instituation, there is absolutely no indication why she was there in a first place, but hey it doesnt matter, right? So what happens that after you get into her room everything change into a weird halucination or you are put in some different dimension, who knows and its up to you find your daughter...The thing is that this game is a lot as a Slender man in its gameplay, you are looking for a lost pages from the daughter diary, sometimes there are some items, but that is essencialy it. The one and the biggest plus is that this game is randomly generated, which brings a replaybality, and as far as i see it is quite effective in how it is build, the main problem here is the main villain, the Hat man is for one absolutely awful, he could not scare you even if you would the biggest chicken in the world and for worse he just making very cheap random apparations which prevents you to do anything, and that is most annoying thing, the game doesnt even follow it own rules where in the diary you are told that putting off a flashlight and crouch will make him go away, well that doesnt work, i waited like this 10 minutes and he just stands there like a ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ so forced game over. And thats the thing, really often it happens that you will get in the hall where is floor missing and you cant cross and right in that moment the ♥♥♥ appear and you cant do anything about it, i lost my progress like this like thousand times and when you have achievments that says do it without saving this will ♥♥♥♥ you off...The graphics are very simple, music non existing, sounds try to jump scare you all the time, movement reminds me sailing on the boat but it is playable, i have to give a credit for a voice acting, its not great but also its not awful and actually i found this good for such a cheap game, it seems that they carred...Overal, this is a game which you can buy, but i hardly find any reason why, the only plus is the price and random generating but that will hardly do for a long time, i will play more just for the sake of achievments, but after that i will gladly forget it...

content:
, 2016
												For starters, this game is an indie horror game. I usually have an open mind about indie games, and not pay any mind to Steam reviews. I decided to try it out right now, and I wish I hadn't even bothered trying it out. Yes, I don't have much time spent on the game, but it's so bad, I couldn't stand to waste more of my time with it. So, you are a parent of a child who goes missing in a mental asylum, and you go in to search for her. Little does the player's character know, the asylum has nobody in it, except for the Hat Man and his Shadow People. The main objective is to run through the asylum, collecting journal pages and avoiding the Hat Man and his Shadow People. Yes, this already seems like a slender man clone, and I can tell you, it essentially is. The two differences between the two are: 1) The map randomly generates as you go, so you can easily get lost. 2) There are obstacles in the way of you progressing, so there are puzzles in this nightmare of a game. All in all, this game had a lot of potential, but it was really wasted, just like my time playing it.

												I love the horror genre and don't scare easily so I figured 0.49 wasn't much money to risk if I didn't like it. This is amazingly atmospheric and so engaging. I set the resolution to 1920x1080 and quality to Fantastic, turned out the lights and turned up my headphones. The graphics and audio are actually really good. The game has a dark, gritty feel to it so I'm guessing that's where all the bad quality reviews are coming from. The controls are wasd standard by default, but you can customize them to your liking. Movement felt pretty fluid with no lag. I became completely engrossed had more "wtf was that???" moments than I've had in quite awhile. When the HatMan ate my soul (on toast with jam?) and I turned on the lights to find out who put poo in my shorts, I was amazed that only 12 minutes had passed. I spent more time petting my cat to calm down than I did playing the game. No, I wouldn't pay 60 bucks for it, but I feel great about what I did pay. Do yourself a favor and get this.

content:
1, 2014
Early Access Review
								This game is utterly terrifying. The first time I played this I thought it would be just one of those boring repetitive jump scare games, but I was wrong. The build up towards your death is the most terrifying; not the death itself, as the loud ghostly noises, the creepy whispering when you get close to the journals,  the sounds of the hat man crawling above you; rattling the ceiling panels or a wheel chair ghostly pushed makes you think that he's right around the corner, behind you or in a door way which keeps you on edge throughout. The thing that I would like to be improved on is when the hat man finally pops up, as for me it wasn't that scary since he appeared at the end of the corridor where I could easily see him and didn't even chase me. So to improve on this you should make him appear from behind you,  grab you through a missing celling panel or try and grab you though a toilet, as there are so many of them. Also it would be awesome if you added flares to light up rooms that you don't want to go in and make the torch flicker or go out to add even more scares. Just to say this is an early access game; it won't be a fully perfect game, so don't buy this if you’re looking for a finished game and just wait until it comes out. But honestly this game is so worth getting if you love indie horror games and is just amazing, to say that it’s an early access game.

content:
, 2014
Early Access Review
								If you're looking for a new Horror game that presents a great atmosphere and makes the hairs on the back of your neck stand up, The Hat Man: Shadow Ward just might be for you. Taking inspiration from Amnesia: The Dark Descent's ambiance, puzzle/collection-based objectives from a variety of games, and cues from psudo-folklore-derived games like Slenderman, The Hat Man has a lot of familiar and tried-and-true aesthetics while presenting new gameplay elements that are quickly becoming extremely popular for video games, especially in the Horror genre--namely, that it's very replayable. The map generates randomly, and if you stray too far from any one spot, it will have changed completely when you try to return to it. If there's one thing that the Horror genre in general relies on, it's atmosphere. As a music composer/writer, I can say with great confidence that what I say next cannot be easily refuted, which is thus: A game that desires to scare, unsettle, unnerve, and frighten, must take great care in creating an experience that tips the audience off-balance, makes them lose their footing, and just when they think they're back on their feet, you pull the rug out from under them. If a Horror game cannot disturb and create suspense, it is operating completely wrong. Now, of course, your mileage may vary, and various games may not neccessarily scare you. But, for me, anyway, The Hat Man does a great job at creating suspense and keeping me on my toes; like watching the fishing reel scene from Jaws, you'd be utterly amazed at what happens when you just focus on the ambience and the sound effects. In truth, they can sometimes be quite scarier than what's actually trying to scare you. In this regard, I think the developers of this game chose a great collection to work with. This game relies on building suspense and atmosphere rather than relying on conventional jump scares like most other Horror games. In fact, there's only maybe a handful of them in this game, if you can even call some of them so. A refreshing and welcome change of pace, in my opinion.All-in-all, a fun game. I can't wait to see what is added and done in the final release. If it's great already, I can scarcely imagine what will happen in the future. To the developers, I say great job, and keep at it.

, 2014
Early Access Review
								Absolutely terrifying!The atmosphere is so thick with terror and the desire to just not progress further. It's actually to the point where I need to conjure up bravey to press on in certain circumstances.There are a couple of things that I absolutele WISH you guys in the developement team could consider:(these are all things that I expected to happen because of my paranoid nature in-game)1: Sound lures the Hat Man to you vicinity (Also encourages stealth and focus in a very trying atmosphere)2: The ability to possibly see him on top of the fallen ceiling-spaces (to encourage a panic causing possibly more trouble)3: Footsteps, which either i couldn't hear in all the terror, or they just haven't been added yet. (maybe a good echo depending on the acoustics of the room too!)4: A reflection in a mirror that perhaps isn't broken (which could show the Hat Man behind you on occasion)5: Perhaps a darker atmosphere to emphasize how important the flashlight or matches are to the player.6: See the Hat Man PASS a corridor ahead. Where he completely crosses the threashhold of an intersection in front of you. (I have never seen him do that, he's only ever crossed halfway and turned to run at me)7: Seeing the Hat Man peek out from corners (just a little touch to mess with the player)8: Maybe even getting captured by the Hat Man only to wake up in a completely unfamiliar area without the flashlight?9: upon opening a door, he would be on the other side, to attack you; could directly correlate to the above suggestion to where opening doors could lead to your capture and loss of the flashlight (this in my opinion would make players who experience this more likely to not want to open a door in the future, leading to more gameplay)These are all just things that have crossed my mind during my TINY time of gameplay and while watching countless let's plays. Also in my opinion, it's the little things that most don't notice that are the most terrifying.Because when someone DOES notice something small- that's not actually a trick of the eye, then they WILL continue to see other small things that might not all be genuinely coded. All in all, I give the game 9.5/10 terror-induced-crapsI hope to see more of the small things in this BIG game!-TJ Stratford

content:
2, 2014
Early Access Review
								So far I'm loving this game. It does remind me a bit of Slender, but without the annoying mechanic that fuzzes over the camera .Graphics: 7/10: It has a very creepy and proper feel to it, but the graphics can get a bit old after a while. Granted it's in beta, so hopefully during official release it will have been touched up. The monster has a rather nice graphics effect when it gets closer and can be seen, granted the ACTUAL Hat Man, is rather hard to make out within the fog till he's right up on you.Sound/Music: 6/10 The sounds and audio are great at first, but after a while they stop being scary, especially when you're having trouble finding pages and are feeling frustrated. The heartbeat mechanic of Hat Man getting closer, is a rather awesome way to tell how close he is and act accordingly, but during the last several pages, when he is popping up all the time (in some of my videos like ever 30 seconds or less), it can get extremely annoying as it becomes all you hear. Still it's in beta, hopefully that'll be polished a bit to where he doesn't pop up so often when you're being super cautious or it isn't as deafening. This is a game you have to play with the sound though, otherwise finding pages will be EXTREMELY hard.Gameplay: 7?/10: I put the ? because I may changed it and move it up, at the present point, I still haven't beaten the game (13 out of ?? pages), though I've finally started to get the hang of it. Hat man is a nice enemy as you can sneak by him and even juke around him (this requires some skill), the stealth works very nicely in the game and leads to some funny survival moments. As you collect more, it seems that real traps start to appear (or there is just a giant pitfall to your death at one point). My only issue with the gameplay is that it's not entirely clear what somethings are for, namely the Matches...I've found Matches, I think they unlock more pages (as I get stuck on 7 pages, find a box and boom I start finding more), maybe a tiny bit of clarity on that...granted could be a journal page I haven't gotten to read yet. Overall: 7/10 likely to improve up with future edit. It's a good game, if you like this type of game. It could be a little more clear on some issues and have some audio configuration options (there is no way to effect the sound which means if you record, you'll be lower the games sound level during editing). I'd say buy it, especially before it gets closer to finished and increases in price.

content:
9, 2014
Early Access Review
								Hat Man=Actually a really well made game! My first impression of the game was that once you get in to the shadow realm or whatever you want to call it, very creepy and atmospheric. Like a lot of other horror games that have been released recently, it's Slenderman essentially. Run around with the threat of a being always present and trying to kill you. That does'nt make the game boring though, don't get me wrong! The game is actually good! It has it's own little story in which you are trying to find your daughter who has "dissappeared". All the notes you pick up are hand written notes by your daughter which give you a really cool back story! So if you are killed by The Hat Man, (who is actually very creepy), you have that feeling of, "Hey! I want to go back in there, and find out what happened to my daughter!" The game is very interesting and actually makes you want to complete the game and get the story, instead of some Slender games in which you just collect the notes for the sake of getting notes. Overall I give the game a 7.5/10. Great atmosphere, the sounds are really nice and creepy, and the plot behind it makes you want more. Good game.

Early Access Review
								The hat man is a horror game, which upon first inspection seems rather unfrefined.However, the game itself provides the user with a disturbed atmosphere, with both the sound and visual design being almost flawless.Although the user is not currently provided with a clear understanding of objective (we thought it ended after collecting 5 notes) the game looks like it has a lot of potential should the developers continue to work on this issue.THe hat man himself, however, is a dissapointing, anti-climactic and abrupt end to the game. The model quality lacks and you end up being more afraid of wheelchairs and lights than the hat man himself.PLEASE. PLEASE. Work on the Hat Man, the user should be afraid of him, they should not be able to wander the map for almost an hour without seeing him. Perhaps using mechanics similar to 'One Late Night' would suit the gameplay.I hope you take this into consideration, I look forward to seeing how the game develops.TL;DR Great atmosphere but the Hat Man isn't all he is hyped up to be. It's not just about the review anymore.

Early Access Review
								Backed this project awhile ago, played the Pre-Alpha and pre-Steam Beta, plus this new release.PROS:+Atmospheric (creepy background music)+Tense (Being chased! AHH!)+Mythos (Backstory is interesting)+Terrifying Antagonist (LOVE the idea behind the Hat Man)+Engine (I actually go "ARG! Not THIS room again)CONS:-Pacing needs work (Finding pages can be hard)-More types of scares needed (too many wheelchairs)Overall I love this game. It's a work in progress, so they listen to people.The CONS are minor things, bound to be edited and tweaked. The concept of changing rooms is a great way to keep the game fresh. Very proud to be a part of this game's development!SHOULD YOU BUY IT: YES.SCORE: 8/10, with an easy 10/10 when finished!

												If you enjoyed the original Slender game, you'll probably enjoy this. There is a lot to like about this indie game:- The sound effects are pretty creepy, and the music is lovely and sinister.- I love the mechanics used, there is a lot to be thinking about as you go.- I think some of the rooms are randomly generated each time you play a new save? (don't quote me on that though) Which if they are is a nice touch, and makes the game a little more challenging. Like how in slender the pages aren't always spawned in the same places every time, but there are a finite amount of locations to find them. - The voice acting isn't bad. The actual reading is good but there have been times I've not been sure about the dialogue. Could just be personal taste though. There is a part where your character makes a joke... and I was kind of like... is this really the time? Focus! Like I say though, could just be me. Overall some of the voice acting is actually very good and this minor detail isn't at all enough to put me off.- The art style is pretty cool. Very immersive but just unreal enough to freak you out. It reminds me of the game "Deep Sleep" if you wanted to make it 3D rather than 2D. Some of the images in it are very similar and that game sh*t me up when it was just pixels, so this more life-like game is a lovely bag of nope.- I will note though that the sensitivity of the mouse felt super high and it was very much a case of flailing around, something you'd have to get used to? Occasionally ended up bumping into walls instead of going through doors. :/Would totally recommend it though. Loving it. Can't wait to finish it and get the whole story which on the whole is shaping up rather nicely!I recorded myself playing the first part for my gaming channel if anyone wants to see the game being played a little and see what they are in for:

I think it's pretty safe to say that no one likes starting from the beginning, (or close to it) that's usually when people start to lose interest. 												I'll give you the rundown of the Pro's and Con's of this game and if you should buy it or not.Pro's:This game has a decent atmosphere and an okay sound track. The creature chasing you is pretty creepy and the way you know he's close is a pretty good idea, you're flashlight starts flickering a little and so you know you need to get the hell out of there. Finding pages isn't that hard since you'll start hearing loud whispering when you come near one, it makes it a lot easier since it would just blend in witheverything else in the game. Graphics are nothing special but not ugly by any means.Con's:Now the level you go through is pretty bland and everything pretty much looks the same without any sense of progression. It's also very linear exept for the occasional choice in differing paths. The creature that's after you is creepy, but not scary. The game will eventually turn into "run away from monster and quickly pick up notes". He will not really scare you for about 98% of the game. The items you pick up are also pretty stupid like the axe you just leave behind after using it once. also at some parts you have to use particular items to continue, this will either cause you to back track a bit, or die to the creature chasing you.Over all, I would only say buy this on a steam sale when it's under $0.30 since you really won't be losing that much money if you happen not to like the game.This game gets a 6/10.

												At first the game lures you in with a scary atmosphere, and gives you a simple goal to find some pages, and a random ghost for some reason. And for a while, the only thing to scare you is your imagination as you go through a literal endless 1st level that's extremely hard to find anything in, but after a while you learn that this game isn't going to abuse you, it's going to take things slow, maybe a little too slow for a horror game, but then on the second level, it starts getting a little scarier with better ambience, Hatman gets faster and goes through walls for some great jumpscares, as well as an even creepier atmosphere and a little more progress through the story, though not much. Even so, it's a pretty well made game and I'm so excited that the official release finally came. However, there are still some issues that I don't quite like.. Not too big but issues: TOO BIG! Holy crap finding your way through this place and collecting items is harder than a dark souls boss, and progression through 1 level can take maybe an hour if you're not familiar with the game, and seeing the same thing over and over again isn't fun. The second issue is that Hatman only gets harder through levels and not time.I should know, because I'm one of the people who spent an hour on the first level. As you're looking through the first floor frantically looking for missing pages, or an item you may have missed, you get lost easily and well.. It stops being fun. Mostly because Hatman is like a companion you can kill but respawns.. Kind of like Tails in the sonic franchise, he never dies and he will come back later but.. You can kill him again easily. The problem with this is like a battle in skyrim against a townie who can't die, you can hit him over and over and over and over again but he won't go down for good, and the battle is infinite because you can't die to him either. The only option is to step outside and face the guards waiting for you,,,, though in this game that's more like the only option is to keep searching for items..But other than ALL of that, great game!

The map sets you on a fairly linear path at first, soon tossing you hallways and areas that all look the same until you're left wandering aimlessly in pursuit for... something to keep you from falling asleep.The "monster" makes its appearance so quickly and so suddenly that it's neither horrifying nor slightly startling. I just kind of stared at it... dumbfounded. And I jump quite easily. I'm a big sissy.Atmosphere - 2/10 "It could be worse... but just barely."Voice Acting - 2/10 "Ditto."Graphics - 4/10 "Gives you a sense of late 90's PC gaming horror, but causes a reflexive cringe upon looking out a window at a still life photo likely snagged off of Google."Story - 0/10 "Cliché. Overdone. Nothing even remotely interesting."Gameplay - 1/10 "Basic. Boring. Minimal interaction, too much aimless meandering."Sound - 1/10 "Too much random hissing noises and weirdness that grates the nerves in your ears as opposed to filling you with any sense of terror or dread. Voices sound as if they were recorded via somebody's webcam mic. Sound quality in general is massively lacking."All in all, I can't really complain for a sale price of 49 cents. Probably fun to goof around with for a YouTube vid or with friends. Otherwise, this game put me to sleep within the first 5 minutes of playing. However I ventured on, regardless, only to walk into a pit of spikes, suffer an agonizingly god awful screaming sequence and get told that I had to restart from the very beginning because I didn't save. Exited out. Uninstalled. Ain't nobody got time for that.
